finding_info.desc:
Sources that aren't covered by the aggregator are not include in the configuration. The configuration aggregator should be configured with all_regions for the source.
This will help limit the risk of any unmonitored configuration in regions that are thought to be unused.

metadata.Title: Config configuration aggregator should be using all regions for source

Sources that aren't covered by the aggregator are not include in the configuration. The configuration aggregator should be configured with all_regions for the source.
This will help limit the risk of any unmonitored configuration in regions that are thought to be unused.

finding_info.desc: IMDS v2 (Instance Metadata Service) introduced session authentication tokens which improve security when talking to IMDS. By default aws_instance resource sets IMDS session auth tokens to be optional. To fully protect IMDS you need to enable session tokens by using metadata_options block and its http_tokens variable set to required.
finding_info.title: aws_instance should activate session tokens for Instance Metadata Service.

metadata.Title: aws_instance should activate session tokens for Instance Metadata Service.
metadata.Description: IMDS v2 (Instance Metadata Service) introduced session authentication tokens which improve security when talking to IMDS. By default aws_instance resource sets IMDS session auth tokens to be optional. To fully protect IMDS you need to enable session tokens by using metadata_options block and its http_tokens variable set to required.
metadata.Resolution: Enable HTTP token requirement for IMDS

remediation.desc: Enable HTTP token requirement for IMDS

finding_info.desc:
Versioning in Amazon S3 is a means of keeping multiple variants of an object in the same bucket.

You can use the S3 Versioning feature to preserve, retrieve, and restore every version of every object stored in your buckets.

With versioning you can recover more easily from both unintended user actions and application failures.

When you enable versioning, also keep in mind the potential costs of storing noncurrent versions of objects. To help manage those costs, consider setting up an S3 Lifecycle configuration.
finding_info.title: S3 Data should be versioned

metadata.Title: S3 Data should be versioned
metadata.Description:
Versioning in Amazon S3 is a means of keeping multiple variants of an object in the same bucket.

You can use the S3 Versioning feature to preserve, retrieve, and restore every version of every object stored in your buckets.

With versioning you can recover more easily from both unintended user actions and application failures.

When you enable versioning, also keep in mind the potential costs of storing noncurrent versions of objects. To help manage those costs, consider setting up an S3 Lifecycle configuration.
metadata.Resolution: Enable versioning to protect against accidental/malicious removal or modification

remediation.desc: Enable versioning to protect against accidental/malicious removal or modification

risk_details: This provider has not defined a risk for this check.

finding_info.desc: S3 buckets should ignore public ACLs on buckets and any objects they contain. By ignoring rather than blocking, PUT calls with public ACLs will still be applied but the ACL will be ignored.
finding_info.title: S3 Access Block should Ignore Public ACL

metadata.Title: S3 Access Block should Ignore Public ACL
metadata.Description: S3 buckets should ignore public ACLs on buckets and any objects they contain. By ignoring rather than blocking, PUT calls with public ACLs will still be applied but the ACL will be ignored.
metadata.Resolution: Enable ignoring the application of public ACLs in PUT calls

remediation.desc: Enable ignoring the application of public ACLs in PUT calls

metadata.Resolution: Don't use canned ACLs or switch to private acl

finding_info.desc: S3 buckets should restrict public policies for the bucket. By enabling, the restrict_public_buckets, only the bucket owner and AWS Services can access if it has a public policy.
finding_info.title: S3 Access block should restrict public bucket to limit access

metadata.Title: S3 Access block should restrict public bucket to limit access
metadata.Description: S3 buckets should restrict public policies for the bucket. By enabling, the restrict_public_buckets, only the bucket owner and AWS Services can access if it has a public policy.
metadata.Resolution: Limit the access to public buckets to only the owner or AWS Services (eg; CloudFront)

remediation.desc: Limit the access to public buckets to only the owner or AWS Services (eg; CloudFront)

risk_details: This provider has not defined a risk for this check.

finding_info.desc: The "block public access" settings in S3 override individual policies that apply to a given bucket, meaning that all public access can be controlled in one central types for that bucket. It is therefore good practice to define these settings for each bucket in order to clearly define the public access that can be allowed for it.
finding_info.title: S3 buckets should each define an aws_s3_bucket_public_access_block

metadata.Title: S3 buckets should each define an aws_s3_bucket_public_access_block
metadata.Description: The "block public access" settings in S3 override individual policies that apply to a given bucket, meaning that all public access can be controlled in one central types for that bucket. It is therefore good practice to define these settings for each bucket in order to clearly define the public access that can be allowed for it.
metadata.Resolution: Define a aws_s3_bucket_public_access_block for the given bucket to control public access policies

remediation.desc: Define a aws_s3_bucket_public_access_block for the given bucket to control public access policies

finding_info.desc:
The Network Access Control List (NACL) function provide stateless filtering of ingress and
egress network traffic to AWS resources. It is recommended that no NACL allows
unrestricted ingress access to remote server administration ports, such as SSH to port 22
and RDP to port 3389.
finding_info.title: Network ACLs should not allow unrestricted ingress to SSH or RDP from any IP address.

metadata.Title: Network ACLs should not allow unrestricted ingress to SSH or RDP from any IP address.
metadata.Description:
The Network Access Control List (NACL) function provide stateless filtering of ingress and
egress network traffic to AWS resources. It is recommended that no NACL allows
unrestricted ingress access to remote server administration ports, such as SSH to port 22
and RDP to port 3389.
metadata.Resolution: Set a more restrictive CIDR range

remediation.desc: Set a more restrictive CIDR range

risk_details: This provider has not defined a risk for this check.

finding_info.desc:
Security groups provide stateful filtering of ingress and egress network traffic to AWS
resources. It is recommended that no security group allows unrestricted ingress access to
remote server administration ports, such as SSH to port 22 and RDP to port 3389.
finding_info.title: Security groups should not allow unrestricted ingress to SSH or RDP from any IP address.

metadata.Title: Security groups should not allow unrestricted ingress to SSH or RDP from any IP address.
metadata.Description:
Security groups provide stateful filtering of ingress and egress network traffic to AWS
resources. It is recommended that no security group allows unrestricted ingress access to
remote server administration ports, such as SSH to port 22 and RDP to port 3389.
metadata.Resolution: Set a more restrictive CIDR range

remediation.desc: Set a more restrictive CIDR range

finding_info.desc: The root user has unrestricted access to all services and resources in an AWS account. We highly recommend that you avoid using the root user for daily tasks. Minimizing the use of the root user and adopting the principle of least privilege for access management reduce the risk of accidental changes and unintended disclosure of highly privileged credentials.
finding_info.title: The "root" account has unrestricted access to all resources in the AWS account. It is highly recommended that the use of this account be avoided.

metadata.Title: The "root" account has unrestricted access to all resources in the AWS account. It is highly recommended that the use of this account be avoided.
metadata.Description: The root user has unrestricted access to all services and resources in an AWS account. We highly recommend that you avoid using the root user for daily tasks. Minimizing the use of the root user and adopting the principle of least privilege for access management reduce the risk of accidental changes and unintended disclosure of highly privileged credentials.
metadata.Resolution: Use lower privileged accounts instead, so only required privileges are available.

remediation.desc: Use lower privileged accounts instead, so only required privileges are available.

risk_details: This provider has not defined a risk for this check.

finding_info.desc: CIS recommends that all access keys be associated with the root user be removed. Removing access keys associated with the root user limits vectors that the account can be compromised by. Removing the root user access keys also encourages the creation and use of role-based accounts that are least privileged.
finding_info.title: The root user has complete access to all services and resources in an AWS account. AWS Access Keys provide programmatic access to a given account.

metadata.Title: The root user has complete access to all services and resources in an AWS account. AWS Access Keys provide programmatic access to a given account.
metadata.Description: CIS recommends that all access keys be associated with the root user be removed. Removing access keys associated with the root user limits vectors that the account can be compromised by. Removing the root user access keys also encourages the creation and use of role-based accounts that are least privileged.
metadata.Resolution: Use lower privileged accounts instead, so only required privileges are available.

remediation.desc: Use lower privileged accounts instead, so only required privileges are available.

risk_details: This provider has not defined a risk for this check.

finding_info.desc: CIS recommends that you apply IAM policies directly to groups and roles but not users. Assigning privileges at the group or role level reduces the complexity of access management as the number of users grow. Reducing access management complexity might in turn reduce opportunity for a principal to inadvertently receive or retain excessive privileges.
finding_info.title: IAM policies should not be granted directly to users.

metadata.Title: IAM policies should not be granted directly to users.
metadata.Description: CIS recommends that you apply IAM policies directly to groups and roles but not users. Assigning privileges at the group or role level reduces the complexity of access management as the number of users grow. Reducing access management complexity might in turn reduce opportunity for a principal to inadvertently receive or retain excessive privileges.
metadata.Resolution: Grant policies at the group level instead.

remediation.desc: Grant policies at the group level instead.

risk_details: This provider has not defined a risk for this check.

finding_info.desc: You should limit the provision of public IP addresses for resources. Resources should not be exposed on the public internet, but should have access limited to consumers required for the function of your application.
finding_info.title: Instances in a subnet should not receive a public IP address by default.

metadata.Title: Instances in a subnet should not receive a public IP address by default.
metadata.Description: You should limit the provision of public IP addresses for resources. Resources should not be exposed on the public internet, but should have access limited to consumers required for the function of your application.

finding_info.desc: VPC Flow Logs provide visibility into network traffic that traverses the VPC and can be used to detect anomalous traffic or insight during security workflows.
finding_info.title: VPC Flow Logs is a feature that enables you to capture information about the IP traffic going to and from network interfaces in your VPC. After you've created a flow log, you can view and retrieve its data in Amazon CloudWatch Logs. It is recommended that VPC Flow Logs be enabled for packet "Rejects" for VPCs.

metadata.Title: VPC Flow Logs is a feature that enables you to capture information about the IP traffic going to and from network interfaces in your VPC. After you've created a flow log, you can view and retrieve its data in Amazon CloudWatch Logs. It is recommended that VPC Flow Logs be enabled for packet "Rejects" for VPCs.
metadata.Description: VPC Flow Logs provide visibility into network traffic that traverses the VPC and can be used to detect anomalous traffic or insight during security workflows.
metadata.Resolution: Enable flow logs for VPC

remediation.desc: Enable flow logs for VPC

finding_info.desc: Unnecessary access to S3 buckets can lead to unauthorized access or information disclosure.

finding_info.desc:
Storage container public access should be off. It can be configured for blobs only, containers and blobs or off entirely. The default is off, with no public access.
Explicitly overriding publicAccess to anything other than off should be avoided.
finding_info.title: Storage containers in blob storage mode should not have public access

metadata.Title: Storage containers in blob storage mode should not have public access
metadata.Description:
Storage container public access should be off. It can be configured for blobs only, containers and blobs or off entirely. The default is off, with no public access.
Explicitly overriding publicAccess to anything other than off should be avoided.
metadata.Resolution: Disable public access to storage containers

remediation.desc: Disable public access to storage containers

risk_details: This provider has not defined a risk for this check.

finding_info.desc:
You can configure your storage account to accept requests from secure connections only by setting the Secure transfer required property for the storage account.
When you require secure transfer, any requests originating from an insecure connection are rejected.
Microsoft recommends that you always require secure transfer for all of your storage accounts.
finding_info.title: Storage accounts should be configured to only accept transfers that are over secure connections

metadata.Title: Storage accounts should be configured to only accept transfers that are over secure connections
metadata.Description:
You can configure your storage account to accept requests from secure connections only by setting the Secure transfer required property for the storage account.
When you require secure transfer, any requests originating from an insecure connection are rejected.
Microsoft recommends that you always require secure transfer for all of your storage accounts.
metadata.Resolution: Only allow secure connection for transferring data into storage accounts

remediation.desc: Only allow secure connection for transferring data into storage accounts

risk_details: This provider has not defined a risk for this check.

finding_info.desc:
Storage Analytics logs detailed information about successful and failed requests to a storage service.
This information can be used to monitor individual requests and to diagnose issues with a storage service.
Requests are logged on a best-effort basis.
finding_info.title: When using Queue Services for a storage account, logging should be enabled.

metadata.Title: When using Queue Services for a storage account, logging should be enabled.
metadata.Description:
Storage Analytics logs detailed information about successful and failed requests to a storage service.
This information can be used to monitor individual requests and to diagnose issues with a storage service.
Requests are logged on a best-effort basis.
metadata.Resolution: Enable logging for Queue Services

remediation.desc: Enable logging for Queue Services

risk_details: This provider has not defined a risk for this check.

finding_info.desc:
Some Microsoft services that interact with storage accounts operate from networks that can't be granted access through network rules.
To help this type of service work as intended, allow the set of trusted Microsoft services to bypass the network rules
finding_info.title: Trusted Microsoft Services should have bypass access to Storage accounts

metadata.Title: Trusted Microsoft Services should have bypass access to Storage accounts
metadata.Description:
Some Microsoft services that interact with storage accounts operate from networks that can't be granted access through network rules.
To help this type of service work as intended, allow the set of trusted Microsoft services to bypass the network rules
metadata.Resolution: Allow Trusted Microsoft Services to bypass

remediation.desc: Allow Trusted Microsoft Services to bypass

risk_details: This provider has not defined a risk for this check.

finding_info.desc:
Azure Storage supports four versions of the TLS protocol: 1.0, 1.1, 1.2, and 1.3.
Azure Storage uses TLS 1.2 or TLS 1.3 on public HTTPS endpoints, while TLS 1.0 and TLS 1.1 are still supported for backward compatibility.
This check will warn if the minimum TLS version is set lower than TLS1_2. TLS1_2 and TLS1_3 are both allowed.
finding_info.title: The minimum TLS version for Storage Accounts should be TLS1_2 or higher

metadata.Title: The minimum TLS version for Storage Accounts should be TLS1_2 or higher
metadata.Description:
Azure Storage supports four versions of the TLS protocol: 1.0, 1.1, 1.2, and 1.3.
Azure Storage uses TLS 1.2 or TLS 1.3 on public HTTPS endpoints, while TLS 1.0 and TLS 1.1 are still supported for backward compatibility.
This check will warn if the minimum TLS version is set lower than TLS1_2. TLS1_2 and TLS1_3 are both allowed.
metadata.Resolution: Use a more recent TLS version for the storage account

remediation.desc: Use a more recent TLS version for the storage account

risk_details: This provider has not defined a risk for this check.

finding_info.desc:
The default_action for network rules should come into effect when no other rules are matched.
The default action should be set to Deny.
finding_info.title: The default action on Storage account network rules should be set to deny

metadata.Title: The default action on Storage account network rules should be set to deny
metadata.Description:
The default_action for network rules should come into effect when no other rules are matched.
The default action should be set to Deny.
metadata.Resolution: Set network rules to deny

remediation.desc: Set network rules to deny

risk_details: This provider has not defined a risk for this check.

finding_info.desc:
Blob soft delete protects blob data from being accidentally or erroneously modified or deleted.
When blob soft delete is enabled, deleted blobs are retained in the system for a specified retention period.
During the retention period, you can restore a soft-deleted blob to its state at the time it was deleted.
finding_info.title: Storage account should have blob soft delete enabled

metadata.Title: Storage account should have blob soft delete enabled
metadata.Description:
Blob soft delete protects blob data from being accidentally or erroneously modified or deleted.
When blob soft delete is enabled, deleted blobs are retained in the system for a specified retention period.
During the retention period, you can restore a soft-deleted blob to its state at the time it was deleted.
metadata.Resolution: Enable soft delete for blobs with an appropriate retention period

remediation.desc: Enable soft delete for blobs with an appropriate retention period

risk_details: This provider has not defined a risk for this check.

finding_info.desc:
Storage Analytics logs detailed information about successful and failed requests to a storage service.
This information can be used to monitor individual requests and to diagnose issues with a storage service.
Logging should be enabled for at least one storage service type.
finding_info.title: Storage account should have logging enabled

metadata.Title: Storage account should have logging enabled
metadata.Description:
Storage Analytics logs detailed information about successful and failed requests to a storage service.
This information can be used to monitor individual requests and to diagnose issues with a storage service.
Logging should be enabled for at least one storage service type.
metadata.Resolution: Enable logging for at least one storage service (Queue, Table, or Blob)

remediation.desc: Enable logging for at least one storage service (Queue, Table, or Blob)

risk_details: This provider has not defined a risk for this check.

finding_info.desc:
Geo-redundant storage (GRS) replicates your data to a secondary region that is hundreds of miles away from the primary region.
This provides an additional level of durability for your data in the event of a complete regional outage or a disaster.
Options include GRS, RAGRS, GZRS, and RAGZRS for geo-redundancy.
finding_info.title: Storage account should use geo-redundant replication

metadata.Title: Storage account should use geo-redundant replication
metadata.Description:
Geo-redundant storage (GRS) replicates your data to a secondary region that is hundreds of miles away from the primary region.
This provides an additional level of durability for your data in the event of a complete regional outage or a disaster.
Options include GRS, RAGRS, GZRS, and RAGZRS for geo-redundancy.
metadata.Resolution: Configure storage account to use geo-redundant replication (GRS, RAGRS, GZRS, or RAGZRS)

remediation.desc: Configure storage account to use geo-redundant replication (GRS, RAGRS, GZRS, or RAGZRS)

risk_details: This provider has not defined a risk for this check.

finding_info.desc:
Storage accounts should enforce HTTPS for secure data transfer and use a minimum TLS version of 1.2.
This ensures that logs and data stored in the storage account are encrypted in transit.
Azure Storage encrypts all data at rest by default, but transport encryption is also critical.
finding_info.title: Storage account should have secure transfer and minimum TLS version configured

metadata.Title: Storage account should have secure transfer and minimum TLS version configured
metadata.Description:
Storage accounts should enforce HTTPS for secure data transfer and use a minimum TLS version of 1.2.
This ensures that logs and data stored in the storage account are encrypted in transit.
Azure Storage encrypts all data at rest by default, but transport encryption is also critical.
metadata.Resolution: Enable secure transfer and set minimum TLS version to TLS1_2

remediation.desc: Enable secure transfer and set minimum TLS version to TLS1_2

risk_details: This provider has not defined a risk for this check.

finding_info.desc:
Storage accounts should use customer-managed keys (CMK) for encryption to provide additional control over the encryption keys.
Customer-managed keys allow you to create, rotate, disable, and revoke access controls.
They also provide greater flexibility to audit the encryption keys that are used to protect your data.
finding_info.title: Storage account should use customer-managed keys for encryption

metadata.Title: Storage account should use customer-managed keys for encryption
metadata.Description:
Storage accounts should use customer-managed keys (CMK) for encryption to provide additional control over the encryption keys.
Customer-managed keys allow you to create, rotate, disable, and revoke access controls.
They also provide greater flexibility to audit the encryption keys that are used to protect your data.
metadata.Resolution: Configure customer-managed keys for storage account encryption

remediation.desc: Configure customer-managed keys for storage account encryption

risk_details: This provider has not defined a risk for this check.

finding_info.desc:
Infrastructure encryption provides an additional layer of encryption at the infrastructure level.
When infrastructure encryption is enabled, data in the storage account is encrypted twice -
once at the service level and once at the infrastructure level with two different encryption algorithms.
This provides double encryption for enhanced security.
finding_info.title: Storage account should have infrastructure encryption enabled

metadata.Title: Storage account should have infrastructure encryption enabled
metadata.Description:
Infrastructure encryption provides an additional layer of encryption at the infrastructure level.
When infrastructure encryption is enabled, data in the storage account is encrypted twice -
once at the service level and once at the infrastructure level with two different encryption algorithms.
This provides double encryption for enhanced security.
metadata.Resolution: Enable infrastructure encryption for storage account

remediation.desc: Enable infrastructure encryption for storage account

finding_info.desc: Firewall rules should restrict RDP (TCP/3389) access to specific IP ranges. Open RDP access can be a security risk.

metadata.Title: RDP Access Is Not Restricted
metadata.Description: Firewall rules should restrict RDP (TCP/3389) access to specific IP ranges. Open RDP access can be a security risk.

metadata.Title: SSH Access Is Not Restricted

finding_info.desc: Firewall rules should not be wide open to all ports. Lock down rules to only required ports.

metadata.Title: Google Compute Network Using Firewall Rule that Allows All Ports
metadata.Description: Firewall rules should not be wide open to all ports. Lock down rules to only required ports.
metadata.Resolution: Modify firewall rules that allow all ports to restrict to only required ports. Use separate rules for specific port ranges as needed, instead of a single overly broad rule.

remediation.desc: Modify firewall rules that allow all ports to restrict to only required ports. Use separate rules for specific port ranges as needed, instead of a single overly broad rule.

finding_info.desc:
Ensures that Google Cloud's default firewall rules are disabled, as they may be overly permissive and pose security risks.
The default network comes with pre-populated firewall rules that allow broad access and should be replaced with more restrictive custom rules.
finding_info.title: Disable Default Firewall Rules

metadata.Title: Disable Default Firewall Rules
metadata.Description:
Ensures that Google Cloud's default firewall rules are disabled, as they may be overly permissive and pose security risks.
The default network comes with pre-populated firewall rules that allow broad access and should be replaced with more restrictive custom rules.
metadata.Resolution: Replace default firewall rules with custom, more restrictive rules appropriate for your security requirements

remediation.desc: Replace default firewall rules with custom, more restrictive rules appropriate for your security requirements

risk_details: This provider has not defined a risk for this check.

finding_info.desc: Firewall rules allowing broad port ranges can be risky. Ensure rules are as specific as possible.
finding_info.title: Google Compute Network Using Firewall Rule that Allows Large Port Range

metadata.Title: Google Compute Network Using Firewall Rule that Allows Large Port Range
metadata.Description: Firewall rules allowing broad port ranges can be risky. Ensure rules are as specific as possible.
metadata.Resolution: Limit firewall rules to necessary port ranges only. If a wide range is specified, consider splitting into smaller ranges or specific ports needed for your application.

remediation.desc: Limit firewall rules to necessary port ranges only. If a wide range is specified, consider splitting into smaller ranges or specific ports needed for your application.

risk_details: This provider has not defined a risk for this check.

finding_info.desc: Private Google Access allows instances in a subnet to reach Google APIs and services via internal IP, which should be enabled for private networks.

metadata.Title: Google Compute Subnetwork with Private Google Access Disabled
metadata.Description: Private Google Access allows instances in a subnet to reach Google APIs and services via internal IP, which should be enabled for private networks.
metadata.Resolution: Enable Private Google Access on subnets. In Terraform, set `private_ip_google_access = true` in the `google_compute_subnetwork` resource.

remediation.desc: Enable Private Google Access on subnets. In Terraform, set `private_ip_google_access = true` in the `google_compute_subnetwork` resource.

message: Bucket does not encrypt data with a customer managed key.
status_detail: Bucket does not encrypt data with a customer managed key.

finding_info.desc:
Encryption using AWS keys provides protection for your S3 buckets. To gain greater control over encryption, such as key rotation, access policies, and auditability, use customer managed keys (CMKs) with SSE-KMS.
Note that SSE-KMS is not supported for S3 server access logging destination buckets; in such cases, use SSE-S3 instead.
finding_info.title: S3 encryption should use Customer Managed Keys

metadata.Title: S3 encryption should use Customer Managed Keys
metadata.Description:
Encryption using AWS keys provides protection for your S3 buckets. To gain greater control over encryption, such as key rotation, access policies, and auditability, use customer managed keys (CMKs) with SSE-KMS.
Note that SSE-KMS is not supported for S3 server access logging destination buckets; in such cases, use SSE-S3 instead.
metadata.Message: Bucket does not encrypt data with a customer managed key.
metadata.Resolution: Use SSE-KMS with a customer managed key (CMK)

remediation.desc: Use SSE-KMS with a customer managed key (CMK)

risk_details: This provider has not defined a risk for this check.
